hyp_text: Vichy France is the common name of the French State (État français) headed by Marshal Philippe Pétain during World War II. It was an independent ally of Nazi Germany until late 1942 when Berlin took full control. In July 1940 the leader of Vichy France was Philippe Pétain (1856–1951), an aging general who was a hero of the Battle of Verdun of World War I. As soon as it was established, the new government negotiated an armistice with Nazi Germany, which gave Germany control over the north and west of the country, including Paris and all of the Atlantic coastline. However, the French colonial empire remained under the authority of Marshall Pétain’s regime. The government remained in Vichy until 1944, although after the invasion of Normandy (June 6, 1944) its authority was so undermined that it withdrew to Germany. After the liberation, the provisional government of Charles de Gaulle repudiated the Vichy government’s actions.
